blocks.value: Mary Magdalene is one of the most prominent women in the Gospels. She was from Magdala, a town on the western shore of the Sea of Galilee. Jesus cast seven demons out of her (Luke 8:2), and she became one of His most devoted followers.
Witness to the Crucifixion and Resurrection

Mary Magdalene was present at the foot of the Cross during Jesus' crucifixion, standing with the Blessed Virgin Mary and St. John. She witnessed Jesus' burial and was the first person to whom Jesus appeared after His Resurrection. Jesus entrusted her with the message to tell the apostles that He had risen, earning her the title "Apostle to the Apostles."
According to tradition, Mary Magdalene spent her later years in contemplation and penance in France. She is the patron saint of converts, repentant sinners, and contemplative life.
